verses.text: Who is like the wise man, and who knows the interpretation of a matter? A man's wisdom brightens his face, and the hardness of his countenance is changed.
verses.comment: Wisdom transforms not just understanding but a person's outward demeanor. Wisdom in the Bible is depicted as a gift from God. Compare Proverbs, which elevates wisdom as vital to spiritual life. A transformed countenance points to the renewal brought by truth, prefiguring how Christ transforms believers inwardly and outwardly (2 Cor. 3:18).

verses.text: I say: Keep the king’s command because of your oath before God.
verses.comment: The verse emphasizes obedience to authority, rooted in promises before God. This resonates with New Testament teaching on respecting earthly authority (Romans 13:1-2). Obedience is seen as fidelity to divine order, a principle influencing traditions of apostolic succession and reverence for established authority.

verses.text: Do not be hasty to leave the king’s presence or persist in an evil matter, for he does whatever pleases him.
verses.comment: Respecting authority includes patience and humility, especially when facing injustice. The king's freedom prefigures God's sovereignty—reminding believers to trust divine timing rather than rushing judgment. Patience under authority is a test of mature faith.

verses.text: Since the word of the king is supreme, who can say to him, 'What are you doing?'
verses.comment: This highlights the final authority of the king, a motif reflecting God's sovereignty in Scripture (see Job and Isaiah). Submission, properly lived, echoes the humility before Christ, who holds all authority (Matt. 28:18).

verses.text: Whoever keeps a command will know no evil thing, and the heart of the wise knows the proper time and way.
verses.comment: Obedience protects from harm, while wisdom discerns the best approach and timing. The verse subtly teaches that knowledge alone is insufficient without obedience—a principle championed in ecclesial tradition. Wisdom discerns the rhythm of life, as seen in Jesus' timing throughout his ministry.

verses.text: For there is a proper time and way for every matter, though man's trouble rests heavily on him.
verses.comment: Echoing Ecclesiastes 3, God's providence orders every moment. Trouble persists, but recognizing divine wisdom brings hope. This suggests a spiritual discipline: waiting on God and submitting to His order, as modeled by Christ in Gethsemane.

verses.text: For no one knows what will happen, and who can tell him how it will be?
verses.comment: Mankind's ignorance about the future points to our dependence on God's revelation. The limit of knowledge invites humility and trust, celebrated in the spiritual tradition of submitting intellect to faith.

verses.text: No man has power over the wind to control it, nor power over the day of death. There is no discharge in the time of war, nor will wickedness deliver those who practice it.
verses.comment: Human frailty is exposed—no one can escape death or fate. Echoes of Christ calming the storm (Mark 4:39) suggest only the divine can master creation. The futility of wickedness calls for seeking righteousness and sacramental grace.

verses.text: All this I saw, as I applied my heart to all the deeds done under the sun. There is a time when one man rules over another to his own hurt.
verses.comment: Solomon observes the oppression that often results from power. Scripture addresses injustices and the need for order, recalling Christ’s call to humble leadership (John 13:14-15). Spiritual authority must serve, not oppress.

verses.text: So I saw the wicked buried, who had come and gone from the holy place, and they were praised in the city where they had done such things. This too is futility.
verses.comment: The apparent success of the wicked is a theme throughout the Psalms. Coming and going from the holy place suggests ritual without authentic faith—pointing to the importance of sincere worship, a principle upheld across Christian traditions.

verses.text: Because the sentence against an evil deed is not carried out quickly, the hearts of men are fully set to do evil.
verses.comment: Delayed justice leads to greater sin. This insight foreshadows the necessity of just and merciful discipline in the faith community, as modeled by wise leaders throughout Christian history.

verses.text: Though a sinner does evil a hundred times and prolongs his life, yet I know that it will be well for those who fear God, who stand in awe before Him.
verses.comment: Ultimate justice belongs to those who revere God. Temporal blessings for sinners contrast with eternal reward for the faithful—a precursor to Jesus’ teaching on storing up treasure in heaven (Matt. 6:19-20). The spiritual life values awe and holy fear.

verses.text: But it will not go well with the wicked, nor will he prolong his days like a shadow, because he does not fear God.
verses.comment: The contrast between righteous and wicked is motifs throughout Scripture. Just as the righteous are remembered, the wicked fade like a shadow—an image used in Psalms and a spiritual warning to cherish reverence for God.

verses.text: There is futility done on the earth: righteous people get what the wicked deserve, and wicked people get what the righteous deserve. I say this too is futility.
verses.comment: The paradox of suffering and injustice invites reflection on the mystery of God’s providence, which finds resolution in Christ’s suffering and resurrection. Spiritual interpretation sees this as an opportunity for offering redemptive suffering.

verses.text: So I commend joy, for there is nothing better for a person under the sun than to eat, drink, and be glad; for this will go with him in his toil through the days of his life that God gives him under the sun.
verses.comment: Joy and gratitude in everyday life counter the futility described. This is echoed in Christian celebration of the sacred in ordinary things (Eucharist as thanksgiving). Enjoying God's blessings is a sign of trust in His goodness.

verses.text: When I applied my heart to know wisdom and to see the business done on earth—how neither day nor night do people rest in their labor—
verses.comment: The relentless search for meaning reveals human restlessness. Christian tradition teaches that true rest is found only in God, culminating in Christ’s promise of rest for the weary (Matt. 11:28).

verses.text: then I saw all the work of God, that man cannot understand the work done under the sun; however much a person labors to seek, he will not find it out. Even if a wise man claims to know, he cannot truly comprehend it.
verses.comment: Human understanding reaches its limit before the mystery of God. True wisdom is humble and recognizes the need for faith, tradition, and guidance that surpasses mere intellect. This conclusion opens the way for spiritual trust and surrender.
